content: Sprint planning meeting is in 5 minutes. Agenda is in the sprint planning doc.
@WG-async-sprint-planning meeting!

Agenda

  • Sprint retrospective
  • Assign polish issues
  • Identify sprint goals
Let's take a few minutes to make sure the doc is up to date for the last sprint
React with :checkered_flag: when you're ready
/me waits for the doc to go quiescent
We can start talking about the retrospective
Sprint retrospective
How was the last sprint?
Fun to finally work on polish bug!
This is the one where I struggled the most to get my goals done. There was one fewer day I had to work in this sprint, which was probably a factor
Anything that worked well / didn't work well?
ack!
sorry, running slow
I have not worked on my polish bug for 2 sprints and I'm feeling guilty about it
I went overboard and took too many polish bugs, one is still waiting on review, one is fixed and the other is incomplete :grimacing:
I guess for me, "Schedule stakeholder meeting" was kind of a big task (depends on choosing a way of picking a time, waiting for responses etc.).. I just never started on it
but I think it's mostly because I lacked the time
"too many tasks" perhaps
sprints go fast
I think the lesson is: shoot for 1 or at most 2 big tasks

tmandry said:

Anything that worked well / didn't work well?

I used pernos.co to debug rustc. Experience still needs work.

I wasn't fully focused on this async stuff yet, we were able to discuss about the async fns in traits MVP, think about some possible complications and we've done a list of tests. This following sprint I should be more focused on the MVP
I had basically two things on my plate this time and I think it went well. If anything, it made me feel like I should have planned one more task.

pnkfelix said:

tmandry said:

Anything that worked well / didn't work well?

I used pernos.co to debug rustc. Experience still needs work.

Niko tried to show pernos.co to me some days ago, would love to see you doing some stuff, I remember you did a video or something or am I wrong?
nice. well it seems like we are getting more calibrated over time.
Yeah I’ve done a couple screen casts. None with rustc yet.
I’m hoping to get the experience a bit more fine-tuned before I put up a video for it.
please do share stuff that once you do, looking forward to that
same, if the experience is decent I'd be excited to try it
okay, I think we can move on?
@triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
@pnkfelix - I'd be interested in hearing what still needs work with Pernosco, although probably best to do that outside this meeting.
Assign polish issues
Project board
I'm going to stick with mine :)
I am planning to keep the one currently assigned to me, as I unfortunately didn't get to it this sprint
I think I can take a new one; the one I have will (hopefully) just lead to me posting a PR of the same diff that I posted in a comment.
I'm going to stick with mine too. I made good progress last sprint, and I'm hopeful I can finish it off this one.
(I’m skimming the “on deck” list now)
okay, let's update the doc :)
@tmandry are the priorities on the bugs in line with what you expect? I.e. are all the P-high ones higher priority than untagged ones?
I'll keep #66731. Leaving #78543 with the rationale in the ticket for further improvements. @nikomatsakis, would you have time this sprint to review #89734?
Or are untagged ones truly un-prioritized
@Esteban Küber yes

pnkfelix said:

tmandry are the priorities on the bugs in line with what you expect? I.e. are all the P-high ones higher priority than untagged ones?

Hmm. I haven't thought about this or looked at the set of bugs in awhile, maybe @eholk has?
I haven't really been doing much with priority
Generally if it has a P-* tag it was set by the prioritization wg, I think
Okay.
In the past I've used the order on the board as a rough indicator of priority (higher priority on the top)
ah that’s important too
I think the order now is more in line with what was touched last
okay, there are only 2 issues listed under polish for the upcoming sprint
But that's probably helpful for knowing what is fresh in people's mind
if you're carrying one over please copy it up
@eholk what is status on #57017 ? It was assigned to you, but now its back on-deck?
I'm not actively working on it right now, but I'm working on a related issue (#57478)
Okay. I’ll take #87613 and I’ll note it in the doc.
I'll unassign myself until I'm actively working on it
My issue is #71723 -- sorry was a bit distracted -- I guess I should write that in the doc? :)
@nikomatsakis yeah though I already copied up your line from the last sprint :)
general note to be careful when updating the doc, it's easy to miss the brand new sprint when the old one has all this juicy content taking up space on your screen
I think we can move on now
@triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
Identify sprint goals
Now's time to discuss / write these in the doc :-)
Shall we move up the schedule stakeholder item, @tmandry ?
yes

@Santiago Pastorino from before we had these, but I don't know if they're realistic or specific enough, maybe you can come up with better ones?

  • [ ] Desugaring for MVP RFC
    * [ ] Prototype
    * [ ] Put up PR with tests

@tmandry

  • [ ] Write-up a plan for "dyn type adaptation procedural macro" along the lines of this post and try to recruit someone to implement

Thoughts on that?
so.. we have the RFC draft up, I guess "respond to comments" is one thing that will be taking up time, but doesn't seem like a normal sprint goal
I think the goal is probably -- get it to FCP?

tmandry said:

Santiago Pastorino from before we had these, but I don't know if they're realistic or specific enough, maybe you can come up with better ones?

  • [ ] Desugaring for MVP RFC
    * [ ] Prototype
    * [ ] Put up PR with tests

well yeah, maybe we can write them more precisely
let me see what I can do :)
We also have the other two RFCs that I think the goal can be "open them on the repo"
lol "RPITIT"
what a great acronym
remind me, what is RPIT?
maybe its in your blog posts that I still haven’t read
return position impl trait
RPITIT is RPIT.. in traits
oh okay

nikomatsakis said:

We also have the other two RFCs that I think the goal can be "open them on the repo"

remind me.. naming the return types and what else?
RPITIT
oh
I don't anticipate a lot of controversy from that
one is function types, and the other is RPITIT
I think those are plenty of goals for us. I'd like to make progress on more things but it's a good enough start :)
the other thing I was thinking about is preparing the "presentation" for stakeholders meeting
(although I wonder if it should be a doc for folks to read)
yeah, or an agenda at least :)
I was thinking a doc would be cool, but also ideally it'd be like an "open letter"
by that I probably mean it's actually a blog post :)
that would be cool
It seems like we have a lot of goals here though

nikomatsakis said:

tmandry

  • [ ] Write-up a plan for "dyn type adaptation procedural macro" along the lines of this post and try to recruit someone to implement

Thoughts on that?

will this go on the fundamentals repo?

I wrote something very open-ended :)

  • [ ] Write up agenda, doc, slides, or blog post for stakeholder discussion
"agenda" at least feels achievable

tmandry said:

will this go on the fundamentals repo?

maybe...?

I thought maybe on https://github.com/nikomatsakis/ergo-dyn/
probably both :)
and I am not sure if I like that name
not enough pun
exactly
I like dyner
it may have been taken though
oh, right, https://crates.io/crates/dynerr was taken
but that's different :)

nikomatsakis said:

I like dyner

pronounced like "diner" -- as in more dyn
and as in tasty food?
that works, and we don't have to decide here :)
I think we are ready to "present"?

nikomatsakis said:

probably both :)

point being: I would frame this as "one take" not "the take", I'd love to see if people have other ideas (either as PRs to dyner or their own repos)
έργο sorry, scribbling
@Santiago Pastorino did you come up with better desugaring goals? if so we'll put them in the doc
@triagebot shall we present? :)
Unknown command.
oops
@triagebot end-topic shall we present?

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
ok pasting what we have

Async fundamentals

  • [ ] Desugaring for MVP RFC
    * [ ] Prototype
    * [ ] Put up PR with tests
  • [ ] Schedule stakeholder meeting to discuss the MVP RFC and overall plan
  • [ ] Get MVP RFC to FCP
  • [ ] Post RFC for function types with nameable output type
  • [ ] Post RFC for RPIT-in-trait
  • [ ] Write-up a plan for "dyn type adaptation procedural macro" along the lines of this post and try to recruit someone to implement
  • [ ] Write up agenda, doc, slides, or blog post for stakeholder discussion
It's a lot, butI think it's achievable
still seems like a lot :)
alright
The RFCs are mostly written
yeah
so posting them is not very hard
okay

Async iteration

  • [ ] Publish syn-based proc-macro syntax prototype
  • [ ] Advertise above prototype and ask people to contribute alternatives
this sounds great!
this is for a for await like thing?
I had a talk with niko where he convinced me of the value of prototyping the syntax changes out of repo, to encourage people to implement their own
@tmandry the reverse
oh, generators? :)

iterator_prototype! {
    fn* foo() -> i32 { yield 1;}
}

iterator_prototype! {
    iterator foo() yields i32 { yield 1; }
}
okay, cool
the patch I was working on used one in particular (won't say what, because everyone hates it), but doing this out of the compiler lets everyone try things out
I assume this will be nightly only and you're not implementing a generator transform on AST
At least at the start, that's the plan
I have some ideas to make it stable-ish, but they are a long shot
cool!

Polish

Goals:

  • [ ] Write "How to Help" page for wg-async-foundations generally, with links to area-specific pages where appropriate.
  • [ ] Async stack trace planning
    - [ ] Identify examples of current bad async stack traces
    - [ ] Propose manually trimmed versions of bad stack traces
    - [ ] Learn about how any existing stack trace trimming works
@eholk I'm really glad you're thinking about how others can get involved!

Esteban Küber said:

I have some ideas to make it stable-ish, but they are a long shot

I mean the best one is "write an RFC" ;)
wait, who owns the stack trace planning?
Also, @eholk how do you characterize the 'detect dropped variables over yield" work?
I was planning on looking into it, but if you're already thinking about it I'm happy to let you do it.
we might want to define what is meant by "async stack trace" here
@eholk , no, I just wanted to know
I saw async stack traces listed under polish, but there's a one sentence description and I wanted to flesh that out some.
I believe @mw was hoping to do some work there?
Yeah, at least on crash dumps
@nikomatsakis - the dropped variables work is under the issues section, #57478
ok
but all these steps sound like they are focused on improving the definition of the problem itself
which I think is great
makes sense
may I suggest @eholk that you frame this as authoring a doc to be posted to a repo?
that summarizes what you have learned and some of the constraints etc
For stack traces, I was going to start by focusing on the RUST_BACKTRACE=1 case
a "background doc" would be awesome, I'd love to read it
Good idea

in addition to debugging the actual await-chains as a "stack trace" (which @mw seems to be focused on), there's also improving the normal stack traces we have today when you are using async (lots of {{closure#0}} and such to dig through)
In my head the result of this was a doc in the repo, but it's better to make that explicit.

tmandry said:

in addition to debugging the actual await-chains as a "stack trace" (which mw seems to be focused on), there's also improving the normal stack traces we have today when you are using async (lots of {{closure#0}} and such to dig through)

Yes, this latter part was what I was planning to look at.
cool :)

Issues:

  • [ ] Better output when .awaiting on sync fn #66731 (estebank)
  • [ ] (nikomatsakis) Async function leads to a "more general type" error #71723
  • [ ] (tmandry) E0623 highlights wrong parameter in async fn #74256
  • [ ] (eholk) Dropped variables still included in generator type #57478 (part of #69663)
    - [ ] Support branching/merging control flow in analysis pass
  • [ ] (pnkfelix) Strange async use ...; compiler suggestion #87613
these are great. I'm so glad we're pushing on all these papercuts (or worse)
heh, @nikomatsakis it looks like we had two lists of async fundamentals goals going?
oh, did we? :)
yeah I had one at the top, looks like you had one under polish
anyway :)

Tooling

  • [ ] (pnkfelix) resolve non-responsiveness (deadlock?) in tokio-console
  • [ ] (pnkfelix) establish set of issues that are blocking a non-preview release, and make tracking issue for it.
for now this will all be tracked on https://github.com/tokio-rs/console, and conversation is ongoing in tokio discord

tmandry said:

yeah I had one at the top, looks like you had one under polish

oops
those sound like concrete, achievable goals though @pnkfelix
Working on making my life realistic
instead of relativistic
since it's been brought up, I am curious if any background work is going on in the crashdump debugging space
@mw has been looking at it
I think I saw an initiative repo go up once
all I know is that I put @mw in touch with someone from Oxide who is interested
and that there is indeed an initiative repo
https://github.com/rust-lang/async-crashdump-debugging-initiative
cool
we should update the roadmap to point to it!
yes!
I can take that
as another sprint goal. :)
sounds good :)
@triagebot end-topic okay, I think we are ready to wrap up

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
nice meeting, thanks y'all :)

and also

@triagebot end-meeting

Does anyone have something to bring up?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if you're ready to end the meeting.
yes, thanks everyone :) I'm enjoying the sprints a lot and I appreciate everyone's participation here
Thanks, @tmandry!

tmandry said:

Santiago Pastorino did you come up with better desugaring goals? if so we'll put them in the doc

  • [ ] Make a trivial trait with one async fn be lowered to HIR (no type params, no bounds, no lifetimes, no nothing :))
  • [ ] Make a trivial impl for that trait work
